attributes.title: Sample coffee supply chain

attributes.description:
The coffee drinker buys the coffee for $13/pound. This price factors in the roasters' overhead—the weight loss of roasting coffee, employee salaries, electricity and heat, cups and mugs and brewing equipment, and a little bit of profit. 

In this case, the roaster's profit is roughly $1/pound.
attributes.title: Coffee drinker / $13/lb.

attributes.description:
The coffee roaster agrees to purchase the coffee sometimes a year in advance of when it's even harvested. Through the work of the importer especially, he is able to finance the purchase and ensure his coffee is delivered as ordered. 

Once the roaster has the coffee, he roasts it in small batches. The coffee loses about 20% of its weight during roasting, a cost loss of almost $1/pound. 

This particular coffee is roasted for drip brewing and sold and packaged as  "single origin" coffee so that consumers can trace where it came from and learn the story of the farmers of the Chirinos coop.
attributes.title: Roaster / Yummy Coffee / $4.25/lb.

attributes.description:
In addition to dry milling the coffee, the export company, Coffee Traders, Inc., transports it to the coast for shipping and makes all of the shipping arrangements. This is arguably the most complicated logistical part of the process, involving a Tetris game of fitting cargo onto shipping containers, international trade and customs reporting, and negotiating with dockworkers.

The export company earns $.25/lb for their role in milling, resting, and transporting the coffee to the U.S.
attributes.title: Port / Coffee traders Inc / $.25

attributes.description: Coffee grown by farmers of the Chirnos coop in Northeastern Peru. Farmers from the coop are paid $2.75/pound for the coffee. The average cost of production for farmers from this coop is about $2.05, so the farmers profit roughly $.70/pound for this coffee.
attributes.title: Farm / Chirinos cooperative / $2.75
Dry mill / Coffee Traders Inc / $.25/lb.
attributes.description:
An export company, Coffee Traders, Inc., owns and runs a 'dry mill.' Once the coffee is harvested and processed, it goes to the dry mill, where the final processing occurs (the removal of the hull). Coffee is also then "rested" (left in tall mounds for a few weeks to a month), which helps it retain freshness for longer. 

The export company earns $.5
